title: 109_hr2981
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSES. Congress finds that approximately 60 percent of Indian tribe members and Alaska Natives live on or near Indian lands with a high unemployment rate of 45 percent. They own over 197,000 businesses generating more than $34 billion in revenue, with the service industry being the largest sector followed by construction. The service industry is the largest sector for businesses owned by Indian tribe members and Alaska Natives, accounting for 40 percent of businesses and 15.1 percent of total receipts. Construction follows as the next largest sector with 13.9 percent of businesses and 15.7 percent of receipts. Retail trade is the third largest sector with 7.5 percent of businesses and 13.4 percent of receipts. The number of businesses owned by Indian tribe members and Alaska Natives grew by 84 percent from 1992 to 1997, with their gross receipts increasing by 179 percent during that period, outpacing the growth of all businesses. The Small Business Development Center program is cost-effective, with clients generating additional tax revenues of $468,000,000 in 1998, six times the program's cost to the Federal Government. Small businesses owned by Indian tribe members and Alaska Natives saw significant growth in both number of businesses and gross receipts from 1992 to 1997, outpacing all businesses in the same period. Small businesses owned by Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians receiving services through the Small Business Development Center program have a higher survival rate. Business counseling and technical assistance are crucial on Indian lands where similar services are scarce and expensive. Increased counseling under the program has been shown to reduce costs. The Act aims to stimulate economies and foster economic development on Indian lands by assisting in creating new small businesses owned by tribe members. Business counseling and technical assistance are crucial on Indian lands where such services are scarce and expensive. Increased counseling through the Small Business Development Center program has been proven to reduce default rates associated with lending programs. The Act aims to stimulate economies on Indian lands by fostering economic development and assisting in creating new small businesses owned by tribe members. It provides management, technical, and research assistance to these businesses and seeks advice from Tribal Councils on where assistance is most needed. The goal is to ensure full access to business opportunities for Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. The Act aims to stimulate economies on Indian lands by fostering economic development and assisting in creating new small businesses owned by tribe members. It seeks advice from Tribal Councils on where small business development assistance is most needed and ensures full access to business counseling and technical assistance for Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. Small Business Development Center assistance is provided to Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. Small Business Act is amended to provide an additional grant for Small Business Development Centers in eligible States to assist Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians with small business startups and expansions on Indian lands. The Small Business Act is amended to provide a grant for eligible States to assist Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians with small business startups and expansions on Indian lands. Eligible States must have a population comprising at least 1 percent of Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. The Small Business Act is amended to provide grants for eligible States with a population of at least 1 percent Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. Grant applicants must submit required information on goals and objectives for services to be provided using the grant. The Administration may require an application with information on the applicant's goals and objectives for the grant, including the capability to provide training and services to Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians, the location of the proposed Small Business Development Center site, and the required grant amount. The applicant for a grant must provide information on their goals, ability to train and serve Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians, proposed Small Business Development Center site location, required grant funding, and consultation with local Tribal Councils. The applicant for a grant must comply with all requirements of the section, consult with local Tribal Councils, and can receive up to $300,000 in grants for one fiscal year. Matching funds requirements do not apply. Regulations will be provided after notice. The maximum amount of grants a single applicant can receive under this paragraph is $300,000 for one fiscal year. Final regulations will be issued by the Administration after consultation with the recognized Association to establish guidelines for this grant program. The Administration will issue final regulations within 180 days to establish standards for educational, technical, and support services provided by Small Business Development Centers receiving assistance under this paragraph, as well as standards for any required work plan. The Administration will establish standards for services provided by Small Business Development Centers, including work plans, within 180 days. Definitions for terms like 'Indian lands' will also be clarified. The Administration will establish standards for services provided by Small Business Development Centers, including work plans, within 180 days. Definitions for terms like 'Indian lands' will also be clarified, referencing various legal definitions. The term 'Indian tribe' refers to any band, nation, or organized group of Indians in the contiguous United States eligible for services provided by the Secretary of the Interior. The Metlakatla Indian Community, eligible for services provided to Indians by the Secretary of the Interior, is recognized as Indian tribe members. The term 'Alaska Native' is defined as Native in section 3(b) of the Alaska Native Claims. The term 'Native Hawaiian' refers to an individual who is a U.S. citizen and a descendant of the aboriginal people before 1778. The term 'Native Hawaiian' refers to a U.S. citizen who is a descendant of the aboriginal people before 1778 and has sovereignty in Hawaii. The term 'tribal organization' is defined in the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. The term 'tribal organization' is defined in the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. $7,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year 2006 through 2008 for this purpose. Funding limitations apply under this paragraph. $7,000,000 authorized for each fiscal year 2006-2008. Funding limitations apply, in addition to program limitations. Administration can only use funds appropriated in advance for this purpose. The Small Business Act is amended to require Small Business Development Centers to seek advice from tribal organizations on how to assist Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians.
